pullRequest.body:
Basic Properties of Profinite Group
Co-authored-by: Jujian Zhang <jujian.zhang1998@outlook.com> Nailin Guan <3571819596@qq.com>

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#16648~~
* leanprover-community/mathlib4#16959
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Could you try to modify this to show that `ProfiniteGrp`Â has all limits, and not just limits of finite groups?

It seems to me that `ofContinuousMulEquivProfiniteGrp` is never used in the construction of limits in profinite groups. I would suggest removing all the stuff related to `ContinuousMulEquiv` from this PR and opening a new, independent PR with that (where you also develop more API for it, as Kevin suggested).

> It seems to me that `ofContinuousMulEquivProfiniteGrp` is never used in the construction of limits in profinite groups. I would suggest removing all the stuff related to `ContinuousMulEquiv` from this PR and opening a new, independent PR with that (where you also develop more API for it, as Kevin suggested).

There is one, #16961 ready for constructing the APIs , `ofContinuousMulEquivProfiniteGrp` would be used in #16906 and #16918

> > It seems to me that `ofContinuousMulEquivProfiniteGrp` is never used in the construction of limits in profinite groups. I would suggest removing all the stuff related to `ContinuousMulEquiv` from this PR and opening a new, independent PR with that (where you also develop more API for it, as Kevin suggested).
> 
> There is one, #16961 ready for constructing the APIs , also it would be used in #16906 and #16918

And do you confirm that `ContinuousMulEquiv` is really not used in this one, so that you can remove it following @dagurtomas 's suggestion?

> > > It seems to me that `ofContinuousMulEquivProfiniteGrp` is never used in the construction of limits in profinite groups. I would suggest removing all the stuff related to `ContinuousMulEquiv` from this PR and opening a new, independent PR with that (where you also develop more API for it, as Kevin suggested).
> > 
> > 
> > There is one, #16961 ready for constructing the APIs , also it would be used in #16906 and #16918
> 
> And do you confirm that `ContinuousMulEquiv` is really not used in this one, so that you can remove it following @dagurtomas 's suggestion?

I am sure about this, I can remove it from this one and left it to #16906 and #16918
So this PR should only contain changes to the `ProfiniteGrp`Â file
All the stuff about closed/open subgroups is also irrelevant to the construction of limits

> All the stuff about closed/open subgroups is also irrelevant to the construction of limits

if compared with #16959 the only difference is in `ProfiniteGrp` now
Oh, but you should make those two independent

completely independent to other things now
closed subgroup would be added in #16959
continuousMulEquiv would be refined in #16961

Oof, something went wrong here, the diff is horrible. I think the easiest solution is to closed this and open a new PR based off the current master, where you only add the changes to the `ProfiniteGrp` file from this PR
I left some comments, the most important one being the implementation of a `ContinuousMulEquivClass`.

```suggestion
* `ofContinuousMulEquivProfiniteGrp` : If a topological group has a two-sided continuous
```

```suggestion
* `ofClosedSubgroup` : A closed subgroup of a profinite group is profinite.
```
Should typeclass inference already be picking this up?
I don't think so, the continuousmulequiv and profinitegrp even the totally diconnected of homeomorphic are all newly added by me not as a class, I still didn't solve these problems.

```suggestion
/-- A closed subgroup of a profinite group is profinite. -/
```
Will this cause problems if I am working in `FiniteGrp.{u}` and I have some category `J` which is just Nat with a -> b if a >= b? Then w=v=0.
I think it is jujian who design the universe level, sorry that I don't know clearly about these problems.
@jjaassoonn This is for you then ðŸ˜„

No, the current design asks the universe level of the the finite groups to be bigger than that of the indexing category:

```lean
#check @limit â„• _
-- limit : (F : â„• â¥¤ ProfiniteGrp.{u_1}) â†’ Subgroup ((j : â„•) â†’ â†‘(F.obj j).toProfinite.toTop)
```

So if the indexing category, the `ProfiniteGrp` can be anything

```suggestion
/-- Verify that the limit constructed above has projections to the `FiniteGrp`s
```
I think that this structure needs a proper API (e.g. `ContinuousMulEquivClass`, `ext`, `refl`, `copy`...) and should probably be its own PR.
Maybe I can start a new PR to solve this. So where can I learn from to write these APIs?

I agree with @kbuzzard that some API is needed (you can have a look at lines 136-186 of the file Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Equiv/Basic.lean where they are defined); but I think that even before that you should consider extending the `MulEquiv` class as explained in line 100 there.
Thank you, I would start a new PR as soon as I am finish the PRs for Profinite
So you are going to put this on hold?
Don't forget an additive version of this
I would try to do this as soon as possible, right after fixing this PR and making the old proofs to fit the new definition (there are like thousand lines depending on the limit of profinite group)
Did I remember wrongly or you defined the class of closed subgroups in another PR?
yes, I defined it, maybe I should change the dependency.
Well, if you have the class for closed subgroups, you should have `(H : ClosedSubgroup G)` as variable.
sorry that it is still only a structure, I think I need to learn about the APIs to work on it.

No, it is me that was unclear, I am sorry. If you have a look at [Subgroup.Normal.mem_comm_iff](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Subgroup/Basic.html#Subgroup.Normal.mem_comm_iff) (I just picked up the first result about subgroups, there is nothing specific about this example), you see that once you have a class like `ClosedSubgroup` you can declare `H` to be a term of type `ClosedSubgroup G` instead of imposing that it is a subgroup _and_ it is closed. So the statement should look like 
```lean
def ofClosedSubgroup {G : ProfiniteGrp} (H : ClosedSubgroup G) : ProfiniteGrp :=...
```
OK, I would rearrange the PRs as soon as possible.
rearranged, it is now stated as you suggested

```suggestion
* `FiniteGrp.limit` : the concretely constructed limit of finite groups as a subgroup of the pi-type
```
Do you mean inverse limit? At any rate, you should use a consistent wording: either injective/projective or direct/inverse (possibly agreeing with what is already used in other parts of the library).
Sorry that I don't know the math clearly. I think I prove it satisfies the universal property in the file.

I think this is just a matter of English, not Math. Direct limits (aka Injective limits) are Colimits; and Inverse limits (aka Projective Limits) are limits. Here you develop limits, so line 189 should say " inverse limit"; then I also suggest that you have a look if in the library we call them inverse or projective and you align this (three lines above you write "projective"...).
These does not seem to be needed. Why are they added?
Sorry that this part isn't design by me, maybe you should ask Jujian Zhang for it. I can at least try to rearrange them now.
@jjaassoonn Can you comment on this?
It is now removed,  so it won't matter much.

This seems a bit strange to me. Why don't you add the local instance that every finite group is a Topological group? BTW: I would put most/all of these material in a namespace, whereas it is now in `_root`.
This has nothing to do with groups, it is also true for topological spaces. Cannot you borrow anything from the library? Have you tried?
Why do you need to introduce fresh variables `A` and `B` with their universes? Can't you use the trilion of spaces already in scope?
fixed

```suggestion

variable {J : Type v} [SmallCategory J] (F : J â¥¤ ProfiniteGrp.{max v w'})

namespace FiniteGrp

/-- Concretely constructing the limit of topological group as a subgroup of the  pi-type. -/
def limit : Subgroup (Î  j : J, F.obj j) where
  carrier := {x | âˆ€ â¦ƒi j : Jâ¦„ (Ï€ : i âŸ¶ j), F.map Ï€ (x i) = x j}
  mul_mem' hx hy _ _ Ï€ := by simp only [Pi.mul_apply, map_mul, hx Ï€, hy Ï€]
  one_mem' := by simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Pi.one_apply, map_one, implies_true]
  inv_mem' h _ _ Ï€ := by simp only [Pi.inv_apply, map_inv, h Ï€]

def profiniteGrpToProfinite : ProfiniteGrp â¥¤ Profinite where
  obj G := G.toProfinite
  map f := âŸ¨f, by continuityâŸ©

instance : CompactSpace (limit F) := inferInstanceAs
  (CompactSpace (Profinite.limitCone (F â‹™ profiniteGrpToProfinite.{max v w'})).pt)
```
This works, for example, because your `limit`Â is defeq to the limit in `Profinite` (in line with Filippo's comment about `limit_closed_in_pi_type`)
If I write as you suggested, do I need to verify the universal property again? (I guess no?)
I think your current proof will more or less work
reconstructed
@dagurtomas But don't we have the same result for topological spaces so that we can deduce this one from that?

I guess you mean something like this? It broke the proofs of `map_one'`Â and  `map_mul'` (sorried below), but that shouldn't be too hard to fix.

```lean
/-- Verify that the limit constructed above satisfies the universal property. -/
def LimitConeIsLimit : Limits.IsLimit (LimitCone F) where
  lift cone := {
    toFun := ((Profinite.limitConeIsLimit (F â‹™ profiniteGrpToProfinite.{max v w'})).lift 
      (profiniteGrpToProfinite.mapCone cone)).toFun
    map_one' := sorry
    map_mul' := sorry
    continuous_toFun := ((Profinite.limitConeIsLimit (F â‹™ profiniteGrpToProfinite.{max v w'})).lift 
      (profiniteGrpToProfinite.mapCone cone)).continuous }
```
Yes!

The `fac`Â field is then handled by automation, I think the `uniq` field can be easily solved using `(Profinite.limitConeIsLimit (F â‹™ profiniteGrpToProfinite)).uniq` after proving that `profiniteGrpToProfinite`Â is faithful.

Like this:
```lean
uniq cone m h := by
  have : profiniteGrpToProfinite.Faithful := sorry 
  apply this.map_injective 
  simpa using (Profinite.limitConeIsLimit (F â‹™ profiniteGrpToProfinite.{max v w'})).uniq
    (profiniteGrpToProfinite.mapCone cone) (profiniteGrpToProfinite.map m) 
    (fun j â†¦ congrArg profiniteGrpToProfinite.map (h j))
```

Here is the whole thing:

```lean
/-- Verify that the limit constructed above satisfies the universal property. -/
def LimitConeIsLimit : Limits.IsLimit (LimitCone F) where
  lift cone := {
    toFun := ((Profinite.limitConeIsLimit (F â‹™ profiniteGrpToProfinite)).lift
      (profiniteGrpToProfinite.mapCone cone)).toFun
    map_one' := by
      apply SetCoe.ext
      ext j
      exact map_one (cone.Ï€.app j)
    map_mul' := fun _ _ â†¦ by
      apply SetCoe.ext
      ext j
      exact map_mul (cone.Ï€.app j) _ _
    continuous_toFun := ((Profinite.limitConeIsLimit (F â‹™ profiniteGrpToProfinite)).lift
      (profiniteGrpToProfinite.mapCone cone)).continuous }
  uniq cone m h := by
    have : profiniteGrpToProfinite.Faithful := sorry
    apply this.map_injective
    simpa using (Profinite.limitConeIsLimit (F â‹™ profiniteGrpToProfinite)).uniq
      (profiniteGrpToProfinite.mapCone cone) (profiniteGrpToProfinite.map m)
      (fun j â†¦ congrArg profiniteGrpToProfinite.map (h j))
```

Unfortunately automation didn't kick in properly in the proofs of `map_one` and `map_mul`. Might be because of some missing simp lemmas in the `Profinite`/`CompHaus`/`TopCat` limit API.
I got stuck when proving it, can anyone help? I found nothing to use about the multiplication.
Thank you, I add the faithful as an instance. 20 lines less than the unmodified ones.
this should probably be called `limitCone`
Yes! See [here](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html)
I forgot to change the stlye after deleting `FiniteGrp` , sorry
`x` is actually just `ofLimit F`, but maybe the complicated type is on purpose

pullRequest.title: feat(Topology/Group/Profinite): limits in the category of profinite groups
